learning_outcomes.description: Explain the unique design issues that need to be considered when designing hypersonic vehicles.
Determine the most appropriate type of hypersonic test facility for a given hypersonic flow scenario and evaluate the test conditions generated in that facility.
Explain how gases behave in the high temperature environment experienced during hypersonic flow and how this influences hypersonic vehicle design.
Evaluate the thermodynamic properties of high temperature gases.
Evaluate the heating and forces experienced by hypersonic vehicles.
Evaluate the effect of viscous boundary layer flow on hypersonic vehicles.
Estimate the degree of rarefaction of gas flows and explain why it is important to be able to characterise these flows in this manner.
Evaluate the forces and heating experienced by vehicles and spacecraft in low density, rarefied flows.

assessments.task_description:
Applied Class problems will be issued on Blackboard to students just before the scheduled Applied Class. The staff running the Applied Class will host the class in person at the scheduled time. The teaching staff will answer questions and explain the task to be completed individually during the Applied Class. Solutions to some or all of the Applied Class problems will be presented and discussed during the course of the Applied Class.

The assessment for each Applied Class question is full marks (worth 1%), part marks (worth 0.5%), or zero marks (worth 0%). The total mark is then the mean average of your mark for each of the questions for that week. Full marks requires that you make a reasonable attempt at the question by selecting appropriate theory and methodology from the lecture material and applying it to the question. Even if your final answer may be incorrect and/or you have made some mistakes, you will still have attempted most of the question in some form. Part marks is awarded if an appropriate but limited attempt is performed, such as completing only a small amount of the question. Zero marks would constitute either not doing a question at all or very incorrectly attempting the question, such as applying an inappropriate analysis to the question.

Work must be submitted individually, however, students are actively encouraged to collaborate with group members in completing this learning activity.

Submission is online via Blackboard at 2:00 PM the next business day after the Applied Class.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission is online via Blackboard at 14:00 the day after the applied class.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date:
13/04/2026 - 24/04/2026

Lab reports are due by 14:00 four calendar weeks after the date that the experiment was performed.
assessments.task_description:
Experiments performed in the UQ 'Drummond' reflected shock tunnel. A reflected shock tunnel is a common type of hypersonic test facility used to further the understanding of hypersonic flow. A teaching assistant will perform experiments on the facility in front of the students and students will analyse provided data using techniques taught in class.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Please refer to Blackboard for the marking criteria.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission is online via TurnItIn on Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

Applied Classes

Applied Class problems will be issued on Blackboard to students just before the scheduled Applied Class time. The teaching staff will answer questions and explain the task to be completed individually during the Applied Class. Solutions to some or all of the Applied Class problems will be presented and discussed during the course of the Applied Class.

Work must be submitted individually, however, students are actively encouraged to collaborate with group members in completing this learning activity.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08

learning_activities.topic:
Shock Tunnel Laboratory Experiment

In this practical a teaching assistant will perform experiments in a small reflected shock tunnel, a common hypersonic test facility. After the practical students will compare and evaluate the results in the context of the theory presented in class.


Learning outcomes: L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
